questions.text: Identify the image shown below? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Maxillary sinusitis

 

Explanation: 

 

The CT image shows maxillary sinusitis because:

 

  • Clear hypodense thickening in the maxillary sinus
  • Involvement of maxillary sinus with mucosal thickening/opacification
  • Anatomical landmarks visible: 
    • Orbit above
    • Maxillary sinus below
    • Ethmoid cells medially
    • Cribriform plate superiorly
  • Disease appears to be spreading into nasal cavity, suggesting possible antrochoanal polyp

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Frontal sinusitis

 

  • Frontal sinuses not clearly visible in this cut
  • Would be located superior to orbits
  • Different radiological appearance

 

Option C. Ethmoidal sinusitis

 

  • Though ethmoid cells are visible medially
  • No significant pathology in ethmoid region
  • Would show opacification of ethmoid air cells

 

Option D. Sphenoidal sinusitis

 

  • Sphenoid sinus not visible in this cut
  • Would be seen at nasopharyngeal level
  • Located most posteriorly among all sinuses

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Most common in adults because ostium locates higher than floor level and drainage is against the gravity.
  • Pain over upper jaw present.

questions.text: An infectious disease has its incubation period as 5-14 days, with its median incubation period being 10 days. The quarantine of contacts traveling to a new country should be done for: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 14 days


Quarantine is the process of separating and restricting the movement of healthy individuals who may have been exposed to an infectious disease, to prevent its spread. Quarantine is typically implemented for the maximum incubation period of the disease, which is the time between exposure to the infection and the onset of symptoms.

 

In this case, the maximum incubation period is 14 days. Therefore, quarantine should be conducted for 14 days to ensure that if symptoms develop, they will appear within this period, confirming the need for isolation and treatment.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Quarantine should be conducted for the maximum incubation period of the infectious disease to ensure that symptoms will manifest within that time, confirming whether a contact becomes a case.

questions.text: A child is brought to the hospital with features of respiratory distress and biphasic stridor. There is a history of upper respiratory infection. The radiograph is shown below. Mark the correct diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute laryngotracheobronchitis

 

A child with respiratory distress and biphasic stridor and given radiograph points to a diagnosis of acute laryngotracheobronchitis.

 

 

LARYNGOTRACHEOBRONCHITIS (CROUP)

 

  • Viral infection of glottis & subglottic region
  • Caused by Parainfluenza virus
  • Symptoms: hoarse voice, coryza, mild Tachypnea

 

Treatment –

 

  • Nebulized racemic adrenaline (1:1 mixture of d & I isomers)
  • A single dose of dexamethasone (0.3--0.6 mg/kg, intramuscular) reduces seventy, if given within the first 24 hours.
  • Antibiotics not indicated

 

NOTE -

 

Croup decreases in lying down position and Laryngomalacia increases on lying down

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute epiglottitis: Acute epiglottitis patients, usually 3-6 years of age, present with acute sore throat, high fever, muffled voice, inspiratory stridor, marked dysphagia and drooling. The patient looks toxic and sits in tripod position, sitting upright, leaning forward with chin up. Treatment is IV Ceftriaxone. Lateral neck X-ray reveals thickening of the epiglottis (thumb print sign).

 

 

Option C. Foreign body in glottis: Aspiration of foreign body may result in localized area of wheeze, hyperresonance and reduced air entry. Foreign bodies are removed through a rigid bronchoscope.

 

Option D. Laryngomalacia: Laryngomalacia is M/C cause of congenital laryngeal anomaly.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute laryngotracheobronchitis (croup) is a viral infection of the glottis and subglottic region, often caused by the Parainfluenza virus, and presents with respiratory distress and biphasic stridor.

questions.text: A patient with gastrointestinal symptoms and neurological symptoms underwent a blood examination whose peripheral smear image is provided here. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Abetalipoproteinemia

 

The image provided shows red blood cells with irregular, spiky projections, known as acanthocytes.

 

Acanthocytes (also known as a spur cell) are characterized by asymmetrical and irregular projections, unlike echinocytes, which have evenly spaced projections.

 

Acanthocytes are strongly associated with abetalipoproteinemia, a rare disorder caused by a defect in the microsomal triglyceride transfer protein, leading to impaired fat absorption and deficiency of lipoproteins like LDL and VLDL. Echinocytes are typically observed in conditions like uremia or burn injuries.

 

 

Abetalipoproteinemia presents with a combination of gastrointestinal symptoms (such as malabsorption) and neurological symptoms (like ataxia and neuropathy) due to deficiencies in fat-soluble vitamins, especially vitamin E. The presence of acanthocytes in the blood smear is a hallmark of this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uremia: Uremia can lead to the formation of burr cells (echinocytes), which have regularly spaced projections. However, these projections are symmetrical and differ from the irregular projections seen in acanthocytes.

 

Option B. Burns: Burn injuries can also lead to the formation of burr cells (echinocytes) due to alterations in red cell membrane structure caused by thermal damage. The symmetrical projections of echinocytes are distinct from the asymmetrical projections of acanthocytes.

 

Option D. Hereditary spherocytosis: This condition is characterized by spherical red blood cells (spherocytes) due to a defect in the red cell membrane proteins. It does not present with spiky projections like acanthocytes, making it an unlikely diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acanthocytes, or spur cells, are red blood cells with irregular, spiky projections associated with abetalipoproteinemia, a disorder characterized by fat malabsorption, vitamin deficiencies, and neurological symptoms.

questions.text: Which drug is used as a first line management for postmenopausal female with osteoporosis?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bisphosphonates

 

OSTEOPOROSIS

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • So, osteoporosis characteristically has normal calcium, phosphate and alkaline phosphatase levels.
  • Bone Mineral Density is measured by DEXA (Dual Emission X-ray Absorptiometry) Scan and it is matched to DEXA scan of 30-year-old individual of the same sex and T score is calculated.

 

 

  • Etiology:

 

 

  • Imaging:
    • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae.

 

 

Codfish vertebrae

 

  • Singh’s Index is used for osteoporosis grading.
  • Treatment: Drugs used in osteoporosis are:
    1. Inhibit resorption: Bisphosphonates (drug of choice), Denosumab, calcitonin, estrogen, SERMS, gallium nitrate.
    2. Stimulate formation: Teriparatide (PTH analogue), calcium, calcitriol, fluorides.
    3. Both actions: Strontium ranelate
       
  • Bisphosphonases (pyrophosphate analogs) bind to the surface of hydroxyapatite crystals and inhibits resorption.
  • These drugs are not metabolized and are excreted intact in urine.
  • Their t 1/2 is 1-10 years and cessation of treatment does not lead to rapid bone loss (as occurs with estrogen replacement therapy).
  • These drugs decrease the incidence of vertebral and non-vertebral fractures.
  • These are the drugs of choice in postmenopausal osteoporotic females.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Raloxifene. Selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) act as estrogen antagonist in breast tissue and as an agonist in bone. Raloxifene selectively stimulates estrogen receptor in bone and is used in treatment of osteoporosis. It reduces risk of breast cancer also.

 

Option C. Estrogen. Hormone replacement therapy is the mainstay of bone loss prevention in postmenopausal osteoporosis with estrogen treatment. Daily dose of 0.625 mg of conjugated estrogen in combination with progestins are recommended. Progestin is essential (even though it has no independent effect on bone) to reduce the risk of developing endometrial cancer (due to estrogen).

 

Option D. Combined OC pills. Combination oral contraceptives (COCs) alleviate climacteric symptoms and might have a positive effect on BMD. Of note, progestin is the dominant component over estrogen in COCs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bisphosphonates are the first line drugs or drugs of choice to treat osteoporosis in post-menopausal females.

questions.text: The type of pelvis commonly associated with occipitoposterior and face to pubis is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 

 

 

The anthropoid pelvis is characterized by a larger anteroposterior diameter compared to its transverse diameter, giving it a vertical oval shape. This type of pelvis is commonly associated with occipitoposterior positions and the "face to pubis" delivery pattern, where the baby's face presents toward the pubic symphysis during delivery. The anthropoid shape often causes the baby's head to rotate into a posterior position, leading to a higher likelihood of occipitoposterior presentations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gynecoid pelvis: The gynecoid pelvis is the typical female pelvis with a round shape and balanced anteroposterior and transverse diameters. It is most favorable for vaginal deliveries and is not commonly associated with occipitoposterior positions.

 

Option B. Android pelvis: The android pelvis is heart-shaped, narrower, and typically has prominent ischial spines. It is more commonly associated with obstructed labor and deep transverse arrest rather than occipitoposterior or face to pubis presentations.

 

Option D. Platypelloid pelvis: The platypelloid pelvis is characterized by a very wide transverse diameter and a flat shape, which often leads to delayed engagement of the fetal head. It is not associated with occipitoposterior positions but can lead to asynclitism and face presentations.

 

Educational Objective:


The anthropoid pelvis is the pelvic type most commonly associated with occipitoposterior positions and the "face to pubis" delivery pattern.

choices.text: Femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve

questions.text: Which of the following structures is contained within the femoral canal? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Answer: D. Lymph node of Cloquet

 

The femoral canal is the medial compartment of the femoral sheath, which is a funnel-shaped sleeve of fascia enclosing the upper 3-4 cm of the femoral vessels. The femoral canal contains a lymph node of Cloquet or Rosenmüller, lymphatics, and a small amount of areolar tissue. This lymph node drains the glans penis in males and the clitoris in females. The femoral canal is about 1.5 cm long and about 1.5 cm wide at its base, with its upper end called the femoral ring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral artery - This is incorrect because the femoral artery is contained in the lateral compartment of the femoral sheath, not the femoral canal.

 

Option C. Femoral vein - This is incorrect because the femoral vein is contained in the intermediate compartment of the femoral sheath, not the femoral canal.

 

Option D. Femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve - This is incorrect because this nerve occupies the lateral compartment of the femoral sheath along with the femoral artery, not the femoral canal.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The femoral canal is the medial compartment of the femoral sheath containing the lymph node of Cloquet (Rosenmüller), lymphatics, and areolar tissue, making it a potential site for femoral hernia development, especially in females due to their wider pelvis

questions.text: Instilling a particular idea in people’s mind and not affecting their thought process is a type of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Health Propaganda

 

Health propaganda is a method of communication aimed at instilling a particular idea or belief in people's minds without engaging their thought process. Unlike health education, which appeals to reason and encourages reflective thinking and skill development, health propaganda is more emotion-driven and does not foster independent thought or critical analysis. The objective is to influence behavior quickly and effectively, often without the support of scientific evidence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Health Awareness: This involves disseminating information to make people aware of health issues, but it does not necessarily instil a specific idea nor does it bypass the thought process.

 

Option C. Health Education: Health education involves a reasoned approach where individuals are informed and encouraged to think critically about health-related issues. It promotes reflective behavior and skill development.

 

Option D. Health Promotion: This is a broader concept that encompasses health education and activities aimed at improving overall health, but it does not specifically focus on instilling ideas without thought.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Health Education versus Propaganda/Publicity

questions.text: The classic Unhappy Triad (O' Donoghue's Triad) involves injuries to all of the following structures, except: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Posterior Cruciate Ligament (PCL)

 

O'Donoghue's Triad, also known as the "Unhappy Triad," consists of three specific knee structures that are commonly injured together in sports: the Medial Collateral Ligament (MCL), Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL), and Medial Meniscus. The PCL is not part of this classic injury pattern. This triad typically occurs when a valgus force is applied to the knee while it's in a flexed position with external rotation, commonly during contact sports.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medial Meniscus - This is incorrect because the medial meniscus is actually part of O'Donoghue's Triad. It is often damaged alongside the ACL and MCL when the knee experiences a valgus force with rotation.

 

Option B. Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL) - This is incorrect because the ACL is an essential component of O'Donoghue's Triad. It prevents anterior translation of the tibia and is commonly torn in this injury pattern.

 

Option C. Medial Collateral Ligament (MCL) - This is incorrect because the MCL is a key component of O'Donoghue's Triad. It resists valgus forces at the knee joint and is typically the first structure damaged in this injury pattern.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

O'Donoghue's Triad consists of injuries to the ACL, MCL, and medial meniscus (often remembered as MAM), while the PCL is not included in this classic injury pattern.

questions.text: A male patient presents to the emergency department. The arterial blood gas report is as follows: pH 7.2, pCO2 81mm Hg, and HCO3 40 mEq/L. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Respiratory acidosis

 

The arterial blood gas (ABG) report shows a pH of 7.2, which indicates acidosis (normal pH: 7.35-7.45). The partial pressure of carbon dioxide (pCO2) is elevated at 81 mm Hg (normal range: 35-45 mm Hg), indicating that the acidosis is due to a respiratory cause, as CO2 retention leads to respiratory acidosis.

 

The bicarbonate (HCO3) level is elevated at 40 mEq/L (normal range: 22-28 mEq/L). This elevation suggests that the kidneys are compensating for the respiratory acidosis by retaining bicarbonate to buffer the excess hydrogen ions, indicating a chronic component to the respiratory acidosis.

 

In summary, the primary disturbance is respiratory acidosis, evidenced by the elevated pCO2, and the elevated bicarbonate suggests a compensatory response by the kidneys, characteristic of chronic respiratory acidosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory alkalosis: Respiratory alkalosis is characterized by a high pH and low pCO2, which is the opposite of the findings in this ABG report.

 

Option B. Metabolic acidosis: Metabolic acidosis would present with a low pH and a low bicarbonate level. However, in this case, the bicarbonate is elevated, not decreased, indicating the primary issue is not metabolic acidosis.

 

Option D. Metabolic alkalosis: Metabolic alkalosis is characterized by a high pH and elevated bicarbonate, but without the accompanying high pCO2. The presence of high pCO2 and low pH indicates the primary disturbance is respiratory, not metabolic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A blood gas report showing low pH and high pCO2 with compensatory elevated bicarbonate indicates respiratory acidosis, often with a chronic component if the bicarbonate is significantly elevated.

questions.text: What is Gaisböck syndrome? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Relative polycythemia

 

Gaisböck syndrome, also known as stress polycythemia or pseudopolycythemia, is a condition characterized by an apparent increase in the red blood cell (RBC) mass due to a reduction in plasma volume, typically caused by dehydration. This leads to an elevated hematocrit and hemoglobin concentration without an actual increase in the total number of red blood cells. The condition is termed "relative polycythemia" because the increase in RBC concentration is relative to the decreased plasma volume rather than an absolute increase in RBC production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Absolute polycythemia: Absolute polycythemia refers to a true increase in the total red blood cell mass. This can occur due to primary polycythemia (polycythemia vera) or secondary polycythemia due to chronic hypoxia or erythropoietin-secreting tumors.

 

Option C. Severe internal bleeding: Severe internal bleeding would typically lead to a decrease in RBC mass and hematocrit, not an increase.

 

Option D. Myeloproliferative disorder: Myeloproliferative disorders are a group of conditions that involve the overproduction of blood cells in the bone marrow, such as polycythemia vera. These disorders lead to absolute, not relative, polycythemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gaisböck syndrome is a form of relative polycythemia caused by a reduction in plasma volume, often due to dehydration, leading to an apparent increase in red blood cell concentration.

questions.text: A patient presents incidentally with the following findings as shown below. He does not report any discomfort. According to the CEAP classification, what will be the C stage in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) C2A

 

  • Given the scenario showing asymptomatic varicose veins, it corresponds to C2a in the CEAP classification system.
  • C2A: Represents varicose veins (C2) that are asymptomatic (suffix A).
  • The CEAP classification system is used to categorize varicose veins based on their clinical characteristics.
  • The acronym stands for Clinical, Etiologic, Anatomic, and Pathophysiologic factors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. C2S: Represents varicose veins (C2) that are symptomatic (suffix S), meaning the patient would experience symptoms like pain, aching, swelling, or other discomforts. Since the patient reports no discomfort, this is not the correct classification.

 

Option C. C4a: This stage represents more advanced skin changes, such as pigmentation or eczema, due to chronic venous disease. The patient only has varicose veins without skin changes, so this classification is incorrect.

 

Option D. C1: Represents telangiectasia or reticular veins, which are smaller than varicose veins. The image and clinical description indicate larger varicose veins, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The CEAP classification system is essential for categorizing the severity and characteristics of venous disease.
  •  For asymptomatic varicose veins, the appropriate classification is C2a, distinguishing them from symptomatic cases and those with more advanced skin changes.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented with bilateral proptosis, restriction of eye movements, and chemosis. Her thyroid profile showed she was euthyroid. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Thyroid ophthalmopathy

 

  • The clinical scenario suggests thyroid ophthalmopathy.
  • Thyroid eye disease (TED) is the most common cause of bilateral and unilateral proptosis in an adult in the euthyroid state.
  • TED may be associated with Graves’ disease, hypothyroidism, or euthyroidism, and the direct causative connection between thyroid dysfunction and ocular changes is unclear.
  • Main features of TED include lid retraction, proptosis, periorbital edema, chemosis, and restrictive myopathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Orbital pseudotumor: Presents with painful eye movements, periorbital edema, erythema, proptosis, ptosis, diplopia.

 

Option C. Orbital lymphoma: Usually presents in the 7th decade, most commonly observed as a painless palpable mass in the superolateral quadrant.

 

Option D. Orbital cellulitis: Is usually U/L condition with pain, proptosis, and chemosis

 

NOTE: Thyroid eye disease can also, though less commonly, occur in euthyroid patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

THYROID OPHTHALMOPATHY EYE SIGNS:

  1. Stellwag sign- incomplete and frequent blinking
  2. Gifford sign- difficulty while everting the upper eyelid
  3. Jellinek sign- abnormal pigmentation of upper eyelid
  4. Enroth sign- lower eyelid edema
  5. Griffith sign- lid lag on upgaze
  6. Mobius sign- not able to converge eyes
  7. Ballet's sign- one or more extraocular muscle restriction
  8. Von graefe sign- retarded descent of upper lid in downgaze
  9. Joffrey sign- absent crease of the forehead in superior gaze
  10. Kocher's sign- staring and frightened appearance of eyes
  11. Dalyrymple sign- eyelid retraction

questions.text: A farmer had a thorn prick 3 weeks ago and presents with difficulty in opening jaw and muscle cramps. He is also having breathlessness. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tetanus

 

The patient presents with classic symptoms of tetanus, which include difficulty in opening the jaw (trismus), muscle cramps, and breathlessness. Tetanus is caused by the bacterium Clostridium tetani, which is often introduced through a wound such as a thorn prick. The symptoms of tetanus can develop days to weeks after the initial injury, as is the case here with the 3-week history.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Strychnine poisoning: Strychnine poisoning can cause severe muscle spasms and cramps, but it typically presents acutely and is associated with a history of ingestion of the poison rather than an injury. Additionally, strychnine poisoning does not usually present with trismus (lockjaw).

 

Option C. Meningitis: Meningitis can cause symptoms like headache, fever, and neck stiffness, but it does not typically cause muscle cramps and difficulty in opening the jaw in the manner described.

 

Option D. Rabies: Rabies can cause neurological symptoms including hydrophobia and agitation, but it does not usually present with muscle cramps and trismus as seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis of tetanus should be considered in a patient with a history of a wound or injury followed by symptoms such as trismus, muscle cramps, and breathlessness, particularly if the onset of symptoms is delayed.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with complaints of abdominal pain. Further workup showed elevated PTH levels and renal calculi. Which investigation should be done next? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tc-99m sestamibi scan

 

The patient presents with elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels and renal calculi, which are indicative of hypercalcemia. The most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism is a parathyroid adenoma. In this scenario, the appropriate next step in investigation is a Tc-99m sestamibi scan, which is the investigation of choice for detecting parathyroid adenomas.

 

A Tc-99m sestamibi scan is a nuclear medicine imaging technique that is specifically useful for locating parathyroid adenomas. It helps in identifying hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue by using a radiotracer that is absorbed more by the adenomatous parathyroid gland compared to normal tissue.

 

Note –

 

Better answer - Sestamibi SPECT >> Tc-99m sestamibi scan

 

While, Technetium 99m Sestamibi typically offers a 2D representation similar to an X-ray, Sestamibi SPECT (Single Photon Emission Computed Tomography) combines the use of Technetium 99m Sestamibi with CT to create three-dimensional images (used gamma rays). Sestamibi SPECT provides a more detailed and accurate localization of parathyroid adenomas. This can be crucial for surgical planning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Radioactive iodine uptake test: This test is used primarily in the evaluation of thyroid function, particularly in cases of hyperthyroidism. It is not relevant in the evaluation of parathyroid adenomas or primary hyperparathyroidism.

 

Option C. Dexa scan: A Dexa scan is used to measure bone mineral density, typically to assess the risk of osteoporosis. While hyperparathyroidism can lead to decreased bone density, the Dexa scan is not the investigation of choice to identify the cause of hyperparathyroidism.

 

Option D. USG thyroid: Ultrasound of the thyroid can be used to visualize the thyroid gland and detect nodules or other abnormalities. However, it is not as sensitive as Tc-99m sestamibi scan for identifying parathyroid adenomas, particularly when they are small or located in ectopic positions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with elevated PTH levels and clinical features suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism, such as renal calculi, the Tc-99m sestamibi scan is the preferred investigation to localize a parathyroid adenoma.

questions.text: A woman, who is 5 days postpartum, presented with tearfulness, mood swings, and occasional insomnia. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Postpartum blues

 

Postpartum blues, or "baby blues," typically present within a 3-5 days post-delivery with mood swings, tearfulness, and mild insomnia. These symptoms resolve within a week or two.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Postpartum depression: Is more severe and persistent, lasting beyond 2 weeks, often requiring intervention.

 

Option C. Postpartum psychosis: Is a rare, severe condition manifesting with hallucinations, delusions, and potential risk to the infant.

 

Option D. Postpartum anxiety: Involves excessive worry about the baby's well-being, often without the characteristic mood swings of the blues.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Postpartum blues (or "baby blues") is a mild, transient mood disturbance that affects up to 30-75% of postpartum women. Symptoms include mood lability, tearfulness, sadness, and sleep disturbances. It typically occurs within the first week (3-5 days) after delivery and resolves spontaneously within days to weeks. Mainstay of management is reassurance, support, and education.

 

Reference: Textbook of Women’s Reproductive Mental Health, Page No 352

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented for evaluation. During the session, he was quite charming, and there is a history of him behaving nicely with family members. However, he often gets in fights with friends. He was also involved in multiple police cases. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Antisocial personality

 

The description provided in the question fits the criteria for Antisocial Personality Disorder (ASPD). Key characteristics of ASPD include a disregard for others' rights, frequent conflicts with social norms, legal issues, and manipulative or deceitful behavior. This individual displays charm during sessions, which is common among people with antisocial personality, as they can be superficially charming and convincing. The fact that he is often involved in fights and has multiple police cases further supports the diagnosis of ASPD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Narcissistic personality: Narcissistic Personality Disorder is characterized by grandiosity, a constant need for admiration, and a lack of empathy. Individuals with this disorder often talk about themselves, praise themselves excessively, and have a sense of entitlement. This patient's behavior does not include any such characteristics; instead, it focuses on antisocial behaviors.

 

Option C. Schizotypal personality: Schizotypal Personality Disorder is marked by eccentric behavior, discomfort with close relationships, and cognitive or perceptual distortions. There is no evidence in the question indicating any such traits, such as odd beliefs, social anxiety, or unusual thinking.

 

Option D. Paranoid personality: Paranoid Personality Disorder involves a pervasive distrust and suspicion of others. People with this disorder frequently believe others are out to harm or deceive them. This patient shows no signs of suspiciousness or paranoia; his behavior is more aligned with antisocial conduct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antisocial Personality Disorder is characterized by a pattern of disregard for others' rights, often involving legal issues, deceitful behavior, and superficial charm.

choices.text: Positive feedback
Negative feedback
Adaptive control regulation

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms is seen in the baroreceptor reflex? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Negative feedback

 

Explanation

 

Baroreceptors provide negative feedback in response to an increase in blood pressure.

 

Baroreceptors are stretch receptors located in the heart and the adventitia of the blood vessels

 

 

Fig: Regulation of blood pressure by baroreceptor mechanism

 

Fig: Regulation of blood pressure by baroreceptor mechanism

 

Increase in blood pressure → stimulates baroreceptors → Herring’s nerves → glossopharyngeal nerves →nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) in the medulla→ release glutamate and activate the caudal ventrolateral medulla (CVLM) → inhibitions of rostral ventrolateral medulla (RVLM) which is the vasoconstrictor center for the brain and the heart. Simultaneously, this pathway also excites the vagal parasympathetic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Feedforward: Incorrect. Feedforward control involves responses that anticipate changes, typically without a direct sensor feedback component, which is not applicable to the baroreceptor reflex.

 

Option B. Positive feedback: Incorrect. Positive feedback amplifies an initial stimulus, leading to an even greater response. In contrast, the baroreceptor reflex mitigates changes in blood pressure to restore equilibrium.

 

Option D. Adaptive control regulation: Incorrect. While adaptive control involves adjustment based on feedback, it is more complex and typically involves adjustments over time to control parameters. The baroreceptor reflex specifically uses a simpler, direct negative feedback mechanism to quickly counteract changes in blood pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The baroreceptor reflex is a prime example of a negative feedback mechanism in human physiology, crucial for maintaining stable blood pressure by counteracting deviations from an individual's normal blood pressure set point

questions.text: Condition shown below is due to which vitamin deficiency?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin A

 

This is Bitot’s spot shown in the picture due to vitamin A deficiency. There is build-up of keratin located superficially in conjunctiva. This can be oval, triangular or irregular in shape. This is also associated with conjunctival xerosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B:

 

  • Function: Vitamin B is a group of vitamins that includes B1 (thiamine), B2 (riboflavin), B3 (niacin), B5 (pantothenic acid), B6 (pyridoxine), B7 (biotin), B9 (folate), and B12 (cobalamin). These vitamins play various roles in energy production, brain function, and cell metabolism
  • Deficiency Symptoms: Deficiencies in different B vitamins can result in a range of symptoms, including fatigue, neurological issues, anemia, and skin problems.

 

Option C. Vitamin C:

 

  • Function: Vitamin C is essential for the synthesis of collagen, wound healing, and the absorption of iron from plant-based foods. It also acts as an antioxidant, protecting cells from damage.
  • Deficiency Symptoms: A lack of vitamin C can lead to scurvy, which includes symptoms such as bleeding gums, joint pain, and skin issues.

 

Option D. Vitamin K:

 

  • Function: Vitamin K is crucial for blood clotting and bone health. It helps in the synthesis of proteins involved in clot formation and bone mineralization.
  • Deficiency Symptoms: Vitamin K deficiency can result in bleeding disorders and weakened bones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Function: Vitamin A plays a vital role in the growth and development of human cells, controlling the immune system by preventing infections, and activating white blood cells
  • Deficiency Symptoms: Vitamin A deficiency can lead to night blindness, dry skin, poor immune function, and impaired growth and development.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 530

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the Chest X Ray?  (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hollow viscus perforation

 

The chest X-ray shows a clear sign of air under the diaphragm, which is a classic radiographic finding indicating a hollow viscus perforation. This condition typically results from the perforation of any part of the gastrointestinal tract, such as the stomach, intestines, or colon, leading to the escape of air into the peritoneal cavity.

 

The key diagnostic clue in the X-ray is the presence of free air under the diaphragm, which appears as a crescent of radiolucency (dark area) beneath the dome of the diaphragm. This finding is an emergency and requires immediate medical intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Everted hemidiaphragm: This condition would not present with free air under the diaphragm. Instead, it involves the abnormal elevation of one side of the diaphragm due to various causes such as phrenic nerve paralysis, but does not produce the characteristic air under the diaphragm seen in this X-ray.

 

Option C. Intestinal obstruction: While this condition can cause significant abdominal pain and distension, it does not typically result in the presence of free air under the diaphragm on a chest X-ray. Instead, intestinal obstruction is diagnosed via abdominal X-rays or CT scans showing dilated bowel loops and air-fluid levels.

 

Option D. Hyperinflated lungs: This is usually seen in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and would show an increased lung volume and flattened diaphragms on the X-ray, but not free air under the diaphragm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of free air under the diaphragm on a chest X-ray is a hallmark sign of a hollow viscus perforation, which is a surgical emergency

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the OPD as he is always fatigued and has muscle cramps after exercise and the blood sample collected soon after exercise showed low glucose and lactate level. He became normal after resting for a while. Which of the following diseases is he most likely to be suffering from? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) McArdle disease

 

McArdle disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type V): This condition is characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme myophosphorylase, which is essential for breaking down glycogen into glucose for energy during exercise. In McArdle disease, individuals experience muscle cramps, fatigue, and myoglobinuria (the presence of myoglobin in the urine) after exercise due to the inability to access stored glycogen for energy. Low glucose levels and lactate buildup can occur during exercise in individuals with this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hers disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type VI): Hers disease is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme liver glycogen phosphorylase. It primarily affects the liver and leads to difficulties in releasing glucose from glycogen stores in the liver. This condition typically does not manifest with muscle symptoms like cramps or exercise-induced symptoms.

 

Option C. Cori's disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type III): Cori's disease is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme debranching enzyme. It primarily affects the liver and muscles and can lead to muscle weakness, liver enlargement, and hypoglycemia. However, it does not typically present with the specific exercise-induced symptoms described in the case.

 

Option D. Andersen disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type IV): Andersen disease is a rare condition caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glycogen branching enzyme. It primarily affects the liver and can result in liver fibrosis. It does not typically cause muscle cramps or exercise-induced symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 4-week-old infant presents with vomiting and constipation. On examination, a palpable abdominal mass is noted. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CHPS

 

Explanation:

 

Clinical features strongly suggest CHPS:

 

  • CHPS is caused by hypertrophy of the pyloric sphincter, leading to gastric outlet obstruction.
  • It typically presents in males, around 4-8 weeks of age.
  • Electrolyte abnormality: Hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis due to loss of gastric acid and dehydration.
  • Best initial test: Ultrasound abdomen → Shows a thickened pyloric muscle (> 4mm thick, > 16mm long).
  • Treatment: Ramstedt’s pyloromyotomy (surgical incision of the hypertrophied pyloric muscle).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Duodenal atresia: Incorrect as it presents at birth with bilious vomiting and double-bubble sign on X-ray

 

 

Option B. Intussusception: Incorrect as it occurs in infants 6-18 months of age and presents with red currant jelly stools

 

 

Option D. Hirschsprung's disease: Incorrect as it presents at birth with failure to pass meconium within 48 hours and has delayed passage of stools

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

CHPS classically presents at 4-8 weeks of age with non-bilious projectile vomiting and palpable olive-shaped mass in epigastrium.

 

Infantile Pyloric Stenosis (IHPS)

questions.text: A patient with pauci-immune crescentic glomerulonephritis, palpable purpura, myalgia, and pulmonary hemorrhage was found to have p-ANCA positivity. Which of the following is the likely vasculitis in him? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Microscopic polyangiitis

 

Microscopic polyangiitis (MPA) is a type of small-vessel vasculitis that is commonly associated with p-ANCA (MPO-ANCA) positivity.

 

MPA is characterized by multi-organ involvement, including pauci-immune crescentic glomerulonephritis (kidney involvement), palpable purpura (skin involvement), myalgia (muscle involvement), and pulmonary hemorrhage (lung involvement).

 

The presence of p-ANCA is a key diagnostic feature that differentiates MPA from other types of vasculitides.

 

MPA does not usually form granulomas, which is a distinguishing factor from granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener’s), another ANCA-associated vasculitis. The constellation of symptoms and p-ANCA positivity points directly toward MPA as the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA): This condition is typically associated with c-ANCA (PR3-ANCA) positivity, not p-ANCA. Additionally, GPA often presents with granulomatous inflammation, which is not seen in MPA.

 

Option C. Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN): PAN involves medium-sized arteries and typically spares the lungs. It is not associated with ANCA positivity, and patients with PAN do not usually present with glomerulonephritis or pulmonary hemorrhage.

 

Option D. Behcet disease: This condition is an inflammatory disorder characterized by recurrent oral and genital ulcers, uveitis, and skin lesions. It is associated with the presence of anti-endothelial or anti-enolase antibodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Microscopic polyangiitis (MPA) is a small-vessel vasculitis associated with p-ANCA positivity and multi-organ involvement, including the kidneys, skin, muscles, and lungs

 

p-ANCA Positive Conditions:

 

 

Comparison of c-ANCA vs p-ANCA:

questions.text: What is the maximum period of voluntary self-admission under the Mental Healthcare Act 2017?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 30 days

 

Under the Mental Healthcare Act 2017 of India, a person with a mental illness can voluntarily admit themselves to a mental health establishment. The maximum duration for such voluntary admission is up to 30 days. If extended care is needed beyond this period, a fresh admission process is required.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 48 hours: Not the specified duration for voluntary self-admission.

 

Option B. 7 days: Not the maximum duration for voluntary self-admission.

 

Option D. 90 days: Far exceeds the duration mentioned in the act for voluntary self-admission.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Under the Mental Healthcare Act 2017 in India, a person with a mental illness can voluntarily admit themselves to a mental health establishment for a maximum period of 30 days.

 

Reference: Forensic Psychiatry in India, Interface of Indian laws and mental health, 27-28.

questions.text: Which type of aphasia is seen in the lesions of the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Fluent aphasia

 

The posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus is where Wernicke's area is located, which is crucial for language comprehension. Lesions in this area lead to Wernicke's aphasia, which is a type of fluent aphasia. Patients with this type of aphasia exhibit fluent but often meaningless speech and have significant difficulties in understanding spoken language. Their speech is typically characterized by normal flow and articulation but includes nonsensical phrases and incorrect word substitutions (neologisms).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Non-fluent aphasia: This type of aphasia, typically associated with damage to Broca’s area in the frontal lobe, results in slow, labored speech and struggle in forming words, though comprehension often remains intact.

 

Option C. Anomic aphasia: In anomic aphasia, the person can speak fluently and understand speech but has difficulty naming objects and words, typically not linked to damage in the superior temporal gyrus.

 

Option D. Conduction aphasia: This arises from damage to the arcuate fasciculus, the brain structure that connects Wernicke's area to Broca’s area. It is characterized by fluent speech with frequent errors, good comprehension, but poor repetition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Regions anterior to the central sulcus are motor areas and posterior are sensory areas. Hence temporal gyrus involvement causes a fluent aphasia.

 

 

Reference - KV Krishna Das textbook of Medicine 5th edition
